text: This is a solid spot - good food, lots of choices. Only complaint here is that there's often a wait (because its good), and when its full the servers and kitchen are too busy too stay on track. The staff are all friendly but they need more people on busy shifts.

Quite frankly the worst Eggs Benedict I've had in my life. Eggs were fried instead of poached, hardly any hollandaise sauce, basically just a drizzle. And unbelievably it came with lettuce, soggy wet lettuce to be exact....for breakfast? Then the kicker was they charged me extra for home fries.  It had the potential to be one of the best because I was excited about the short rib, sadly was the opposite, won't be back here again I'm afraid.

This is probably my favorite spot for brunch. The biggest plus for me is that it is a very child-friendly restaurant without being a crappy chain or fast food. The food is good and so is the service. When I take my 13 month old with me the staff are always friendly and accommodating (they will often bring some banana slices for him to munch on..no charge)  There are so many yummy choices on the menu it is often hard for me to decide. If I feel like eggs and something more savory I usually get the veggie overload omelet with feta cheese. It is so good and full of lots of veggies not just onions and green peppers...which I find at a lot of other restaurants. If I feel like something sweet I get the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes, light and almost crepe-like compared to the standard buttermilk. The food is fresh and satisfying, not extremely greasy or salty, more like how you would cook at home.  My only cons are that the seating can be tight when the restaurant gets crowded..especially on weekends. The tables are so close along the bench seating it can be hard to squeeze between them to get to the bench (and I am on the slim side) Also, the menu changes a bit with the season, so if you find favorites you might be sad to find them off the menu at times.

I'd have to say that Square Cafe would be my top pick so far for brunch in Pittsburgh.    Its a pretty standard brunch place with cute decor and crowded saturday mornings, with people meeting up to catch up from the week, but it also has a great menu selection, lots of seating, and the portions are on the larger side.  Only complaint I have is that coffee is a little pricey and I know some people like the little mugs they use, but I felt like mine was a little dirty :(.  So far I've only tried the breakfast foods, and all were quite tasty.  Service was also pretty good, even though it's always crowded at Square Cafe.  They also have a large section of seating outdoor, which I love!
I did not enjoy my food. It seemed that the cook had neglected to put any salt in the food whatsoever. Presumably that was intentional as I have experienced this more than once.

Food is as the bad reviews say: Raw eggs, over cooked sausage and a bland pancake that only has taste of protein powder. The only highlight was being seated right away at 8:30 on a Saturday. Otherwise service was rushed and as unfriendly as you can be without getting fired.

First time in. Tried a breakfast sandwich with chicken apple sausage and provolone. It was just ok, nothing exciting. The sandwich was really hot, or maybe specifically the eggs, and I kept burning my mouth with every bite. Not sure if I'll become a regular but might give it another try sometime (after all, I do live a few doors down).

This place is cute an kitschy and hip all at the same time! They are very, very vegetarian and gluten-free friendly and helpful with substitutions on almost any menu item. I love the Brussels sprouts galore this fall, and lots of healthy veggie options.  There's a cute latte and milkshake menu, and bottomless coffee from kiva han.  My tofu scramble was light but filling, and the hot sausage burrito was perfectly filling and spicy without overdoing it. This is one of the very rare places that could please me and my family if we came here as a group... That is rare!

The food was good.  I'm impressed at the number of vegetarian options!  Unfortunately the waitress that served us this morning just can't wait to get us out of there.  She gave us the check without being asked and took the plates away from the table when I asked her for more hot water for my tea.  Very unpleasant experience ..  I would give it another chance due to its vegetarian options and hopefully not have the same waitress.

Came here the first morning I was in Pittsburgh and it couldn't have been better.  Two words.  Perfect.  Bacon.  The Breakfast Eggrolls?  Awesome.  The Bacon, Eggs and Asparagus?  Really good.  Great service in a family friendly, quirky room.  I'd be back all the time if I lived there...

I'm giving this place a 5 star now because of service. They had made a slight mistake on my order with the tot mess and did not put a scrambled egg on the top. I asked our server if this was a change in the item but he said it was just a mistake on their part. I knew they were busy so I knew it was an insignificant problem, but our server returned our bill taking off the tot mess because of the small hiccup. I genuinely appreciate this small act of kindness. Having a business care about their customers like this will undoubtedly make me want to return. Thanks Square Cafe!

Square cafe has the best breakfast I've eaten in Pittsburgh. It was a short drive outside the city and completely worthwhile. The place was packed, but the hostess was extremely professional and efficient in getting everyone seated in a timely manner.  It took only 15-20 minutes on a Sunday morning for us to get to our table. We had the corn beef bene, which was absolutely delicious. It was big chunks of corn beef over rye with braised leaks and poached eggs. It was a very unique spin on eggs Benedict and was perfectly balanced.  We also gluten free pancakes, which I was a bit skeptical of. I have tried many gluten free items before (bread, bagels, muffins) and have always been disappointed. However, these pancakes were by far the best gluten free items I've ever eaten (that classically should contain gluten). They had an amazing texture, which is incredibly hard to do without the use of flour.  I love the classic Pittsburgh spots (Pams, Deluca's), but this place is far better than both.

Decent, unique food but overpriced for what you're getting. Biggest issue was how small the restaurant was. We had a table in the middle and constantly knocked chairs with other tables. Getting to and from the table was the most expensive, makeshift maze money can buy.
The food is excellent, my favorite is the chicken and spinach crepe with Parmesan cream sauce.

A perennial favorite.  The Square Cafe always impresses out-of-towners for breakfast or brunch.  I typically order the specials, but standards like the caprese scramble never fail.  Although you may have to wait for your table on a busy weekend morning, the service is friendly.  The tables are close together, but we made friends with our neighbors.  I was a little disappointed with my most recent visit.  I ordered the polenta special, and the polenta was dry and clumpy.  That being said, the eggs over easy were perfectly cooked.  The coffee hits the spot.

My most visited Pittsburgh spot. I love the colorful decor and staff (who are the epitome of friendly and accommodating). I always look forward to their creative specials, but have a few favorites to fall back on if they don't tickle my fancy. I am also obsessed with the unique square mugs used for all of their incredible hot drinks.    You are destined to find a favorite dish here and fall in love with the cool, quaint cafe in the hip little neighborhood.

The ambience of Square Caf√© is hip and fun, and it's a nice place to take kids, but its food is mediocre and overpriced and the dining area is cramped. My $11 pesto and mozzarella omelette was okay tasting, but overcooked and rubbery. The $2.80 coffee was weak. At least my daughters' French toast was good. Still waiting to find a brunch place in Pittsburgh that serves excellent food.  Our server was very pleasant and the food was served in good time, despite a full house.  UPDATED REVIEW We have since been back to this restaurant on several occasions and my impression of it has definitely improved. Coffee has been consistently very good, pancakes are amazing, and the breakfast burrito I had there recently was fantastic. Not sure if they've upgraded their cooking, but we have been very pleased with their dishes on the whole. Still too cramped, but there's not much they can do about it as long as they are in the space.

As we entered, waitress quickly made eye contact with a smile and had us a table right away. The place has energy and the paint colors and the artwork help keep it up Super friendly staff. The square mugs for coffee are a nice touch for the namesake. Coffee is typical diner coffee. OJ was fresh and cold.   Tons of veggie options - tostada tofu was my choice. Crispy toasta was fine but the tofu, black bean, pepper combo was right on - the salsa tied it together, and for a nice punch, I requested olives on the side. I could do without the aioli, but that's a personal preference. Also got the Challah french toast - can you say HOLLA?!!? Very yummy.   Def will be back when visiting the 'burgh again.
Came with a party of six and left with six happy smiles. Each of us ordered completely different meals and we were all extremely satisfied.
Food was just awesome . I had the crab Benedict . It is so fresh , the servers were nice and it was so nice to sit outside and eat on a calm Sunday morning .
Ur service suks m8 it took 3 minutes for them to get me a slice of cake while others at my table got it in less than 30 seconds

Sooo good. I love this place. I've only gone once but can't wait to go back. If anyone is from the Pacific Northwest, you will feel a little bit closer to home when you see all the lumberjack types with beards and non-traditional families (and traditional ones) that fill the small restaurant. I don't know how they can have such a large menu when the dining area is so small. It's definitely worth the wait, though.   They have interesting and delicious ingredient combinations. The miss-matched dishes are cute, everyone is jammed in and having a great time and great food. The pumpkin walnut pancakes are delicious and so are the veggie omelets. Really, it all looked pretty amazing. Like I said, can't wait to go back!
I've eaten here numerous times. The food is amazing. Service is friendly. Shakes are delicious. Great atmosphere. It never disappoints.
Delicious fresh salad, crepes small but yummy, ample stuffing in omelets.  Love the bottomless coffee and tea. Friendly and professional service.

Food: many, many options for palates of all varieties, many vegetarian and vegan options, great breakfast/lunch/brunch choices, just got a new menu with even more options, everything we've tried is at least good if not great from breakfast burritos to veggie burgers to pancakes to green eggs and ham (really!)  Price: slightly more expensive than a typical breakfast diner, but well worth the cost of admission, the food is fantastic and they offer so many choices you won't be disappointed  Drinks: coffee is amazing, the smoothies are even better, and the coffee bar is great as well, plus try the homemade lemonade  Atmosphere: slightly cramped seating inside but only because there is always a line to be served because the place is so damn good, outside seating extends down the street and is more spaced and cozy, tables and chairs outside are very nice  Service: friendly and fast, always seated quickly even when there is a line, all meals come out together  (+): the location isn't great (see below) but it is right next to Dz Hot Dog Shop which is the best Six-Pack shop in Pittsburgh, the food is phenomenal, anyone who doesn't rate this as one of the top 10-15 restaurants in Pittsburgh hasn't been here  (-): location (who wants to go to Regent Square?)  Would I go back again? Absolutely

I was anxious to try this place after hearing many good things about it, but now that I have, I will not go back!  My 2 friends and I meet for lunch every year during Christmas time to catch up and exchange gifts. We planned to meet at 11:30, thinking that the breakfast crowd would be winding down; yet before the crazy lunch time started. Not so...I arrived a little early (11:15), thinking I would get the table and have a cup of coffee only to find out that they will NOT seat you until your entire party has arrived. We were not seated until after Noon. That's a long time to stand in a very tiny entrance way. We ordered salads which were OK, and coffee. They refilled our coffee twice, and the waitress was nice, but she really wanted us to eat and get going, as the long wait line was still growing after 1pm. When we asked about desserts, she said that they had biscotti and a few cookie choices at the counter but weren't really offering any real desserts. We felt so rushed that we left without exchanging our gifts. This is not a cafe where you can sit and leisurely enjoy a cup of coffee with friends; but rather a "wait, eat & run" type of place...too bad!

Stopped by Sunday around 11am, very busy but I was seated within 15min.  My server was prompt and friendly. The cinnamon swirl pancakes with chicken sausage was delicious. Everything was hot, fresh and delicious. Almost forgot to mention, I had the best chai tea latte ever! If you're in the area definitely give this place a visit.
Favorite breakfast spot in my life right now!!!! I crave the lemon berry pancakes regularly. Deliciousness. Manfriend enjoys the omelet specials and frittatas too. Tasttttttyyy indeed.
Very yummy food. Great specials and large selection of organic, vegan, gluten free, etc. meals. Amazing pancakes. Usually a wait but still so worth it.

Square Cafe is one of my favorite breakfast or lunch spots in Pittsburgh. Delicious coffee in their unique mugs ( I loved them so much I bought a couple for myself). Friendly staff and vibrant atmosphere. Must get the Brussel Sprout hash and if it's on special the Corned Beef hash. Also love their Chorizo Tostada and Salmon Crepes.It's also fun to sit outside and dog watch in the spring, summer, and fall. For Sundays if you can get there early before 9 (?) or very late in the day is best, though the early crowd generally equals quite a few screeching children (which is fine if that suits your needs - it's nice that it is so accommodating to families in the neighborhood). I like going closer to 1 on a Sunday (or just on weekdays) so I don't feel rushed to clear a table and can keep enjoying another mug of after breakfast coffee.

Square Cafe is a great concept: the menu was full of items made from fresh ingredients with unique combinations. The restaurant had a colorful decor and lively patrons. However, I was not super impressed with my brunch, I felt that something was always missing from my food.  One of the pros of the place was that all the food items had a home-style feel while being unique, which I liked. I got the breakfast burrito: chorizo, eggs, and veggies all wrapped up in a flour tortilla. Coming from Southern California, I was expecting one of those famous Mexican-inspired breakfast burritos you can find in tons of mom-and-pop restaurants, full of meat, cheese, etc. However, what I got was mostly eggs and a sprinkling of the other stuff, aka an omelet wrapped in a tortilla. In summary, the overpowering egg was under seasoned and lacked the Mexican spices I grew up loving. For the price, I did not feel that I got what I paid for.  We also got the Cinnabon-inspired pancake. This was amazing. It tasted like a cinnamon roll.  In terms of the service. I understand it was a busy day, but the lady who was taking people's names in line was extremely rude to my girlfriend. She (girlfriend) accidentally stood in the doorway and apologized after she was asked to move. Even after apologizing, she received an eye roll and scoff. I realize that should not influence the rating too much, but it really set the dining experience to an off-note. I prefer not to start my meals being angry.  My experience was not the greatest. Perhaps I ordered the wrong thing. I would love to give this place another shot because it has such great reviews and the menu items sound so promising.

i heard the place was "pricey" but by living in coastal california as i do i found it to be affordable, reasonable and serving portions to be worth the price point. the staff was rather nice. they were friendly. i recommend the steak and eggs with butternut squash. if you are in the square looking for a nice place to have brunch, this is the place.

**Warning: $1.00 per egg surcharge for any egg dish**  This is excessive, if not predatory price gouging, for an alleged egg shortage that might be true for one area of the country (Midwest) but certainly not in PA nor is it a national crisis as they seem to suggest.**. Otherwise, the place is a nice contemporary breakfast/lunch eatery. There is a decent veggie/vegan selection, usual breakfast fares but not greasy like most. The youngish staff are cordial.
Place is always packed (sometimes like sardines), and food is consistently delicious. Try the lemon berry ricotta pancakes--TO DIE FOR! Milkshakes and Nancy B. cookies are also great options.
Excellent breakfast which included really nice fresh vegetables as part of the omelette/hash.
The best thing I have ever had from them is the lime pancakes, it's not on the regular menu so I enjoy there Nutella crepes until the lime pancakes come back again

Home is where ever I'm with you!  We're staying at a hotel and our daughter said: I want sunny-side up eggs & pancakes like you make them mom. The service was great! The food was amazing! And our daughter was extremely happy + their hot chocolate hit the spot!  Thank you!

The food is consistently good here.  The items are a little overpriced, considering you can get the same quality and more quantity at Pamela's.   But for locals it's the only offering,  so I go.  Let me reiterate that the food is consistently good, so I don't mind paying a little more for a good bite.  The filet and sweet potato mash is by far the best thing on the menu for the price,  On the down side pancakes and crepes are generally a la carte, no side of any kind is served with them.. I find that annoying.     The atmosphere is my biggest problem with this place.  The dining room is very small and the foot traffic is a nightmare.  This might be really good new$ for the owners, but it is off putting for those who want a relaxing breakfast.  The seating is not handled with as much grace and poise as I have seen at other busy restraunts manage this blessing of a problem.  Loads of people are crammed into the doorway, there is not a designated waiting area.  You either feel like you are making others uncomfortable by placing your rear in their face as they eat their breakfast OR you are on the recieving end of that discomfort, it's a lose lose.  I am a young 20 something year old, but I have come to Square Cafe with senior relatives, it is certaintly not accomodating to their needs in terms of space or seating.     I would like to give a 2.5 star, which is earned solely by the consistently good food, however a half marking is not possible.  2 is too low, as you will most likely enjoy what is going into your mouth.

I only ordered a organic coffee but this place was super fun inside and the food looked great! My coffee had great flavor. Staff was very warm and friendly. I would enjoy going back some time for breakfast. Indoor and outdoor seating both looked nice.  UPDATE: I went back! I ordered the Holy Lux and it was very good smokes salmon. I loved it!!! My friend ordered the veggie crepes and that was extremely good too. Would definitely eat breakfast here next time I'm in Pittsburg

They serve Eggs Benedict everyday all day. Awesome.  Great selection of breakfast fare in general with a menu to feed the pickiest eaters to the food adventurous.   Simple atmosphere and a great service staff who can pour a mean shot espresso.  Perfect for catching up with a good friend.

This is the second time I've been here and, unfortunately, my opinion has not changed. While I try my best to support locally owned, neighborhood businesses, they also have to do their part...by providing something I'd like to come back to.   Service was lacking for the price and quality of the decor. Our server displayed what I can only describe as "attitude" when we politely asked for a substitution due to a dietary restriction. First she was silent for about 60 seconds and then simply said, "Ummm NO - we don't do that." Well, thank you ma'am!   Also, while I appreciate the fact that they seem to have gone to lengths to put gluten-free options on the menu, unfortunately they were not the tastiest options. The gluten-free corn pancakes had a sour flavor that maple syrup didn't cover...avoid. Also, I thought the homefries my companion got with her omelette were some of the worst I've seen...they were...completely deep fried...more like tiny squares of french fries. In my experience, homefries are supposed to be made from boiled potatoes cut up and sauteed on the grill with onions, etc. and I would expect nothing less for a place that serves $12 omelettes.

We met friends here at 8 am to avoid the rush.  Unfortunately the waitress' agenda of getting us in and out was at odds with our hopes for a relaxing breakfast with friends. The food and coffee was very good as usual but the pushy service made the experience less enjoyable than we had hoped.  I expected better from you Square Cafe!

I ordered the egg white omelet that had apple chicken sausage and asparagus and it was delicious. It came with fresh fruit, and was definitely filling. The coffee is great also. My boyfriend ordered the salmon crepes that were pretty good, but not worth the price. It definitely was not enough food for him. I do like there many healthy and gluten free options on the menu. It's also nice that you can order a single crepe or pancake if you want to just try one. Yes it is a little pricey, but still worth giving it a try. And like most people wrote the staff is very friendly.

I came for brunch on a recent Friday. I had the Brussel (sic) Sprout Hash; my companion had cornmeal pancakes and a side of sausage.  The hash was absolutely phenomenal. I normally experiment with different dishes, but if I return to Square Cafe, I will simply order it again. The sprouts were done as perfectly as I've ever had sprouts (tender, but with a little resistance left in them), the ham and onion provided a good counterpoint, and the ensemble was served over (quite good) grits and under a (nicely runny-yolked) egg.  All the flavors worked well together, and the portion was just right for a robust brunch.  My companion allowed me to sample her cornmeal pancakes, which I found to be a competent version of the offering; the berry preserves were excellent, and pairing the pancake with a bite of sausage is quite nice. The portion size was large -- we were unable finish them.  She also assured me that the coffee was top-notch; I did not partake.  I intend to return; if the hash is consistently this good, I may have found a new favorite brunch place.  ----  Quick update: returned this recent Friday, had the Brussels Sprout Hash again. Was not as good as the previous trip. Sprouts were hard (needed a little more time), and the yolk of the egg was barely runny (needed less time). Hoping this was an off day for the chef, and I didn't just get lucky the first time.  Update 2: returned (again) and had the hash (again), and it was prepared more correctly this time -- slightly softer sprouts and runny yolk very much in evidence.

A little pricey, but the food's really good.  I really love their Benedicts and my girlfriend realy loves their hashes.  The milkshakes are really good too.    Only thing disappointing is that the menu changes and then your favorite thing is gone.  The thing you wanted to order when you were thinking about going there.  Seasonal menu woes.    Also, the home fries are lame.  They're basically home fry shaped french fries.  No seasoning or delicious onions mixed in, they're just fried potato chunks.

Square has a giant menu and the happiest most bustling atmosphere you can find in Pittsburgh on a weekend morning.  Everything is cooked well and delicious, and they're super friendly as well.  The coffee mugs are awesome.  My wife and I always split a nutella crepe with mandarin oranges...so good.  I've had burgers, hashes, omelettes, and probably other things I can't remember, but I know everything has been good.  It would be great if they used NoWait as it can be a bit of a long wait when it's cold outside.

So far I've loved everything I've had here, but especially the pancakes- i order one on the side to complement my breakfasts.  A pregnant woman's privilege!  My husband favors the white bean hash, which i was surprised to like as well- love the rosemary.

I love it!!  It's always busy, especially on the weekend.  The first time I went here, I got crepes with Nutella and strawberries.  They were amazing!  The other time I've gone, I got peanut butter pancakes with bananas and chocolate chips.  The pancakes were really fluffy and the flavors really complemented each other.  It's like eating dessert for breakfast.  The decor is really fun, and I love that they sell artwork by local artists.

The service was excellent! The staff are all very nice and the food was prepared promptly. Probably the fastest I've ever gotten my breakfast! On top of that, the food was superb! Everything was fresh and delicious. There are options for everybody- lots of vegetarian, vegan, and even meat lover choices. I will be coming here a lot more often for my first or second meal of the day! Can't go wrong at this place.

I'm lactose intolerant.   I ordered pancakes, eggs, and bacon. The pancakes showed up at my table with whipped cream on them, even though whipped cream wasn't on the menu, and the waitress didn't mention anything about them. After craning my neck around for my waitress, a different waitress came to my table, and I told her that there's no way that I can eat the pancakes since the cream will make me sick. She took my pancakes away and never returned. My initial waitress didn't seem to notice that anything had happened. I never got replacement pancakes. Nobody came back to refill my iced tea, ever. The rest of the food was so-so, but the service was so bad that I'll never, ever go back.

Come here for breakfast or lunch, as it closes at 3.  The food is solid, American, healthy and varied. And the staff is cool.  Lots of omelettes, crepes, excellent salads, including white bean salad over arugula (and I'm not a salad lover), including burgers, meat and veg.  It's often packed for weekend brunch, and during the week it's often got moms with kids during the lunch rush.  Nothing super fancy, but healthy, good, food at reasonable prices.

The food here always tastes very authentic and delicious. I've gotten the Lox of Love before, and I have to say that the combination of the ingredients they put in made me a very happy customer. I also had their lavender green tea, which was heavenly and something I'd absolutely recommend.  One thing to note is that there is normally around a half hour wait for brunch on weekends, so definitely go early.

Veggie omelette was way over cooked,  hard and dry ... Not good at all ... Very disappointing since I had had better food there a couple of years ago. My companion experienced the same with her omelette. So my advice ... At the very least ... Don't order an omelette ... Especially given the price.

I highly recommend the Square Cafe. Not only do they provide amazing, high-quality food, but they create an atmosphere that is nothing short of absolute relaxation. Depending on how long your party size, the wait usually is not bad--in fact, when I went there with a party of two I was seated instantly outside (which was great!).  Regarding the price of food, I did think that it could have been cheaper; however, I did feel satisfied by the food/drinks that were ordered even though it was around $40 for two people. The prime factor that runs up the tab is definitely the drinks (milkshakes are about $5 each, which is a tad expensive...they are very good though!).  Overall, I think everyone should give the Square Cafe a try--it's hard to go wrong here folks! (By the way, if it's nice out, SIT OUTSIDE! It's great!)

My wife and I went there with a GroupOn coupon.  Parking is free on street.  Braddock Avenue is a busy street but we were fortunate to find a space near the restaurant.  It was 11 a.m. on a weekday and the caf√© was busy but not crowded.  Service was excellent.  My wife requires GF menu and they have a number of gluten free choices.  She had the Brussels Sprout Hash and said it was very good.  I had the Monte Cristo.  It was excellent although I could have done without the greens.  Good sized portions of food.  We would go there again.  Menu is seasonal.

There is always something slightly wrong and rushed about the food. Yesterday, the root vegetable medley had undercooked potatoes which overpowered the other meager root veggies, no seasoning, overcooked egg and burnt ciabatta. The server saw me eyeing the toast and asked Is that too burnt for you? What? Don't serve it burnt! The place is always crowded and clearly they can get away with this.  But shouldn't want to.

Whenever we visit our daughter in Pgh, we always come for breakfast at Square Cafe.  The menu is so creative.  You want bacon and eggs? Fine.  But you want something unique, you will find it here.  I normally won't wait more than 10 minutes for any meal, but i will wait, however long it takes here.  While waiting outside some guy pulled up and asked me why the long wait.  I showed him the menu. on our 8/18/14 visit, i had corned beef hash and eggs.  Whatever image you have of this in your head is wrong.  We are talking chunks of salty lean corned beef, mushrooms and shallots lightly sauteed in sweet butter with tiny potato halves.  All of this sits under two perfected pan cooked over easy eggs.  Add some perfect rye toast and a stunning pottery mug (I bought two) of coffee and you have an unique breakfast for less than what you'ld pay at Dennys.  It is my must visit any time i come to Pgh.

I have mixed feelings about this place.   I came here for brunch with some friends and our waiter was AMAZING. He was really really wonderful. He brought our drinks out super quick and took our orders without us having to wait around for a ridiculous amount of time. We all really liked him. Also, Square cafe also has many options that are vegetarian, vegan, and gluten-free which is definitely a plus.  What I didn't like was how ridiculously LONG the wait was here. If the food was AMAZING - I could understand the lines of adoring customers, but to be honest, the food is just okay. I feel like they nickel and dime you for additions to your meal like if you want sausage in a breakfast burrito that consists of eggs and cheese. My friend got one of the vegan options and didn't like it that much either. It was just okay... I've had better brunch/breakfast foods elsewhere. I also think that the prices are a little steep for what they're serving.   One thing that really turned me off about this restaurant is how everyone is a vegetarian or a vegan, but they want to make it KNOWN that they are. I don't mind if you don't eat meat or dairy products. Even my friend who was with me who is a vegetarian thought it was obnoxious. We felt like we were living in a real life skit of Portlandia. Someone actually got pissy that the restaurant didn't carry vegan butter. They followed up by saying, "ugh, I don't get it, it's so easy to make." During this conversation this person mentioned MANY times that she was a vegan as if NOBODY within hearing distance didn't hear her the first 9 times she said it.   It was so lame. I hope this place doesn't turn into a pretentious place where people hate on you if you don't eat a gluten free diet.   I just have mixed feelings. There were things I liked and things I didn't. I probably wouldn't come back.

My friend and I stopped here for breakfast during a very short visit to Pittsburgh. The people working there were super friendly and made us feel very welcome. We both ordered iced espresso drinks from their "Summer Drinks" menu and they were delicious without being overly sweet. I had their yogurt with honey and granola and added half an avocado (loved this option, even if it *was* a tad pricey) and a side of their chicken apple sausage and loved every bite of my meal!

Came here for brunch with my boyfriend because I heard great things about it. The place is very cute and cozy, and you can opt for outdoor seating too.   Both of us got the Square Breakfast (choice of protein, pancakes and 2 eggs) but we were pretty disappointed by the portion size. I paid around $12 for my plate, which wasn't worth it at all as we both left hungry.   I probably won't come back for the food, but I'd love to try one of their square specialty lattes!

The cute decor, friendly staff, interesting menu, and good coffee made Square part of my weekend brunch rotation, but on more than one occasion I've walked away not 100% satisfied.  I find that a lot of the menu items are overpriced ($10 for crepes with ham and cheese? what?) with a lot of additional dollars and cents for cheese on your sandwich/meat with your omelette, etc. The homefries are good but don't satisfy a hungry stomach... and the breakfast sandwich is quite dry.   Oh. The salsa is very very tasty -- but the menu says its made by a local retailer and not the cafe themselves! Hm.
Square cafe is cute. It's not the most amazing delicious food I've ever had, but it beats Denny's. Their lattes are also really good. I'd avoid eggs and go for the pancakes or French toast.

Tasty brunches, cool mugs, lively decor, and reasonable prices.  Also, a brie crepe--whoa.    This is a place I feel excited about visiting for brunches, but also feel like I can afford.  I think they even have free wifi!  (And, yeah, I can walk there.)
This place is local, quaint, reasonably priced, unique, and friendly. I absolutely loved it. The sunny latte (cinnamon and carmel) is heavenly. It is a new local spot for me!!

Okay, went for lunch last week.  Not the best lunch in the 'burgh!  Daughter had hamburger, she said it was fine (not as good as Burgatory).  I had Hoppin Johnny which was an egg, rice, blackeyed pea, and greens dish.  It said spicy in the menu.  I say it lacked flavor and was dry!  I asked for Red Hot or Tabasco!  Word to the wise:  when you go, order breakfast (during breakfast time)!  Honestly, I've never had a bad breakfast here until this meal.

We stopped in for the first time yesterday and to say that the entire experience was awesome would be an understatement. The food was amazing! I am a vegetarian and my wife and son are not. They had a menu that accommodated both, and it wasn't light on the vegetarian options either. I had the breakfast burrito with soy sausage, my wife had the breakfast sandwich, and my son had the chocolate chip pancakes. Everyone was impressed with the food. Now the service, I am sorry I didn't get her name, but the young lady that waited on us was above and beyond what a waiter or waitress should be. She should seriously teach a class on how to treat customers! She was quick, refilled our glasses before they were empty, spoke to my son like a person. I would go here again and again! VERY HAPPY WE FOUND THIS PLACE! Great job everyone!
Great coffee.   Great staff.    Great ingredients and inventive menu.   Prices are higher because of this...but considering the above they are worth it.

I suggested to my brother, one of my best friends, and his two sisters and girlfriend that we try The Square Cafe last weekend for breakfast, and I am glad that I did. The food was incredible - I had the Square Protein breakfast with a Trail Mix pancake on the side - and the coffee was excellent as well. We had to wait around 20 minutes to get a table, but it was 11:30 a.m. on a Saturday, so a wait for good food is to be expected.  The ingredients are organic, the food is prepared well, and the presentation and service is excellent. You get what you pay for, and in this case, you get quality food. Then again, I don't mind paying for high quality items and service. The bottom line is that good food costs money.  I very much enjoyed the coffee and saw nothing wrong with it. Most people are used to drinking rotgut coffee, so perhaps the coffee at Square Cafe is just something foreign to them. It all depends on what you like I guess.  I will most definitely be back here for breakfast and lunch.

I usually go to square cafe on weekends and I love the outdoor seating and that dogs are welcome. My only complaint is that I wish there was a better wait system. The location makes it difficult to wait because of the size of the space. but not much can be done about that. Food is always excellent and the service has no room for complaints. Love it!

It's a good thing I don't live in this neighborhood because Square Cafe would have all of my money.  The smoothies here are creative and delish.  I crushed a Butter Bean in less than 10 minutes because it was so tasty.   The cafe is on the smaller side so when it's packed on the weekend you can feel overwhelmed. That wouldn't stop me from coming during the morning breakfast rush but some people might mind.  Very large and diverse menu with dishes for just about anyone.   If you're in the area and looking for a good breakfast spot, Square Cafe is your jam.

I had heard so many great things about this place, so when Tim suggested it for brunch on Saturday, I immediately grabbed the car keys.   We opened our brunch with a specialty latte. My Sunny Chai was heaven in a cup. His Cinnamon Bun was a softer, more subtle flavor.   For food, I ordered the Chorizo Crepes. I was upset because they were so delicious, but incredibly spicy. I couldn't take more than a few bites. I had some rye toast to tide me over. Tim had the special - Short Rib Benedict - a brioche bun topped with short rib, an egg, and hollandaise sauce. OH MY. It was the most delicious thing I'd ever had for breakfast. We finished up with some coffee and singing.  The atmosphere of the Square Cafe is so on point - bright, cheery, merchandise for sale, attentive and fast service, delicious food, and a great music playlist.
Food is really bad. They spoilt a nice morning with tasteless food that included bad breakfast and very slow service. Also the menu is expensive. Try Pamela's
Went here for breakfast/brunch with family, including small children. Service was great and food was delicious. Kids gobbled up their French toast. Would definitely go back when visiting Pittsburgh.

had the pancakes and bacon both were good, also brussels sprout hash, very good, this is a place that is busy but worth the wait, theres a reason there's a long line , friendly staff our waiter was very good, would go again

I come early to avoid the children and the social commentary. Never had a bad meal here, ever. I've had roughly 3/4 of the menu. Their salads are so huge and tasty that men eat them. They keep it local, seasonal, fresh and classic.   The people who say the portions are small probably want Pamela's -- the Primanti's of breakfast.

You should know up front that I have a special attachment to the Square Caf√©. I grew up in Regent Square, so I've been rooting for its success from the very beginning. Boy, am I happy to tell you that this place just Keeps Getting Better.  The crowds of people waiting to get a seat (sidewalk caf√© al fresco style if it's warm) should not deter you. The staff is efficient, so get close to your neighbors in the teeny waiting area and just enjoy the local flavor. The good stuff is on its way sooner than you think!  I love that the walls are decorated with local artwork for sale, and the atmosphere just makes me happy. Very bright, clean and retro-modern.   Breakfast/Brunch: A resounding yes. Anything I've had has been delicious. While the menu has changed slightly over the years, I can recommend the side of potatoes (perfectly bite sized, crispy and salty) the tofu scramble that even meat eaters will enjoy and the breakfast burrito (ole!). Meals usually come with a slide of toasted ciabatta. Do yourself a favor and forget your no-carb diet, add a healthy smear of jelly, and ENJOY.  Lunch: I get the same thing every time for lunch, just because it's so good: chicken salad on a wrap with lettuce and tomato, with a side of fries. I almost don't want to write about it, because it will make me HUNGRY. I always promise myself that the next time I'll try something else, because it all looks so good, but I can't cant give up an opportunity for this sandwich. It's creamy and crunchy in all the right places, and the fries will knock your socks off. (The sweet potato fries leave something to be desired, however. Stick with the regular.)
The food is wonderful and the staff excellent.  There's always interesting specials and something for everyone.  Weekends are hectic but worth the wait.
Perfectly cooked omelets, the most delicious hash browns, bottomless coffee in cool mugs, and friendly, attentive service!
I appreciated that they were very kid-friendly but we were served the worst pancakes I've ever had at a restaurant. Unfortunate since we live so close but we won't be returning.
Love this place! The food was excellent and a lot of great selections on the menu.  The atmosphere was relaxed and  comfortable.  I will definitely return.  I had the Greek omelet,  the best!

My first visit to the Square Cafe was fabulous. We were there on a beautiful, sunny Monday and it wasn't too busy. We were seated quickly and our server was prompt and friendly. The atmosphere was so nice--everyone seemed relaxed and happy. Our food was great...there's something for everyone. I have not one bad or even ambivalent thing to say. Would DEFINITELY go back.
Good food, though a bit nuts on the weekend. My biggest complaint is actually a compliment: I wish they were open at nights -- my favorite time to eat breakfast food! Please extend hours!!
Really awesome breakfast and brunch. I got a crab and spinach crepe which rocked! Service is good and they are friendly!

There was definitely good and bad about Square Cafe.    First, the good: I had a fantastic brunch meal.  I had the Brussels sprout hash (caution: not vegetarian) and a single order of the pumpkin walnut pancake.  My hash was served over cheesy grits and had an over easy egg on top.  It was delicious.  The pancake was sweet but not too sweet.  But there was bad: We were forgotten about.  Which is fine, and understandable on a very busy Saturday morning.  But we were made to feel bad about being there, about being forgotten, about wanting more than one cup of $3.00 bottomless coffee, about one member of our party's food being left unmade, about not leaving.  It was such a disappointing experience.

Sunday breakfast 1/14/18 for four of us - had a great time and great food! Our waiter Joe recommended things that were a home run - who knew brussels sprouts could be good for breakfast?! Nice vibe, and the staff were all very attentive. Don't get to Pittsburgh very often,  but will definitely go back!

A local gem! Great family-owned business. Wonderful sense of community, with local artists' work showcased everywhere. Pancakes that are out of this world. Service that is polite and efficient. Very kid-friendly, yet other patrons were all ages. The best breakfast we have had in Pittsburgh, hands down. Would definitely visit again.

I had brunch here with a friend this morning and really enjoyed it! The cafe was very busy but we were seated within a few minutes of arriving. Some of the servers seemed a little grumpy, although our primary server was friendly. I ordered the "Hopple Popple". This dish features three scrambled eggs with a variety of veggies including peppers, onions, chopped fingerling potatoes, spinach and mushrooms topped with Amish cheddar. I loved it. My friend had the salmon crepes, which had smoked salmon, light cheese, herbs and oven-roasted tomatoes. This dish was outrageously tasty and if you're in the mood for a salmon brunch dish, I would highly recommend it. The pieces of salmon on top were a bit dry but, eaten with the sauce, it was delicious. The homefries were serviceable but plain - no onion, peppers, or discernible seasoning. I noted to myself for future reference that they have breakfast burritos on the menu.  They also have a coffee bar with stool seating that offers a wide variety of specialty coffee drinks and teas.

Oh, Square Cafe. I wanted to like you so badly. I've been meaning to come here for years. Then I moved to Chicago, and on subsequent visits to Pittsburgh never made it to Square Cafe. Recently, I saw a Groupon for this restaurant and decided to use it on my trip to Pittsburgh this weekend. I was looking forward to it; the menu looked great and the reviews were good. I went there yesterday, and my entire family was disappointed.  Service was okay -- not the most attentive in the world, but it was decent. The food, though, wasn't good. I had the lemon-berry ricotta pancakes, which weren't cooked all the way through. The middle in two of the three pancakes was uncooked batter. My mom said her hamburger tasted like a frozen patty from the grocery store and had a strange aftertaste. My dad's eggs were cold. And my brother, who will usually eat everything on his plate, ate less than half of his chorizo tostada. My brother and I took our meals in to-go boxes (I figured I could heat up the pancakes the next day and fix the problem of them not being cooked all the way through, but I tried to eat them this morning and they still tasted bad). My mom's burger was mostly uneaten, and to his credit the server asked if there was a problem. My mom said she didn't like it. Most restaurants would take it off the bill at that point, but Square Cafe didn't.  I'm giving it two stars because the restaurant is cute and the coffee is pretty good. I asked for a to-go cup for my leftover coffee, and the server actually brought me a to-go cup of fresh coffee, which was very nice of him. That was one of the few things that bumped this review up to two stars.  Also, it's expensive ($50 for four people before the Groupon). My dad said later that we could have gotten similar, better-tasting food for half the price somewhere else.
Tons of selection. It's always packed so the wait is never fun, but the food is so worth it! Very dog friendly too- they have milkbones in the waiting area and water bowls out front :)
expensive! four of us for lunch was over $100 not including tip. but so good! daily specials are awesome. pumpkin pancakes. red velvet pancakes. turkey sausage. kill me now. so delicious!

Square cafe is a perfect brunch spot. As a Pittsburgh native, I'm familiar with the other local chains and this one is by far my favorite. A lot of variety and solid service. Pittsburgh restaurants tend to start out great and then slowly deteriorate over time, but Square Cafe has avoided this curse.   I give it 4 stars because although the food is really good, it's nothing exceptional. Also they do not offer any alcoholic beverages ( I don't think).

Fantastic food and drinks, friendly staff, and a great atmosphere filled with local art. This is a great place to check out if you're visiting the city or showing some visitors what's great about Pittsburgh. If the weather is nice they even have some nice sidewalk seating to let you drink in the sights and sounds of regent square. If you're looking for a great spot for a delicious and satisfying breakfast or lunch you can't go wrong with the square cafe.

Went to brunch there with a friend and the food was great! My friend had a great groupon so our food was super cheap. The waitress was really friendly and served our food on time, despite the place being packed.

The food is really good, but a little expensive for what it is; the service is apathetic, but not offensive. The milkshake and hot drink menu is expansive and delightful. I really only go when I have out of town visitors, it isn't worth the line or prices if you live in Pittsburgh. But it is perfect for taking out of towners to brunch because it has something for everyone. Square has an extensive menu that is especially great for your vegan and vegetarian friends while still being great for meat eaters- a rare feat.
What a long wait on Sunday morning but totally worth it. Love the location and outside seating if the weather permits... Nice flavor and friendly staff ... Will definitely go back !

This place is such a little gem. We went on a thursday morning that my husband and I randomly took off work. It's a small place and was very busy. I can't imagine weekends. Food came out super quick though and waitress was really friendly and attentive. Coffee was served in awesome mugs. I might buy one next time as they have them for sale. We both had the brussel sprout hash (amazing!) And split an order of apple cinnamon oatmeal pancakes (fluffy vanilla apple deliciousness!) A little pricey but definitely worth it, especially when you're supporting a local businesses!

I went here for lunch with my sister. I have been wanting to go here since they offer vegan options. It's a quirky and young cafe.  I first ordered the johnny cakes with bananas and chocolate chips. On the menu they were marked as vegan, so I was excited. When it came out my sister noticed a slab of butter on the plate, so I took it back. It turns out that they're not vegan and the menu was misprinted. They didn't even know, and I had to show them.   I also think the menus were their new fall menus as well. But they were nice about it, and I got the actual vegan fig pancakes instead. It was an inconvenience and they need to fix it. I also wish they had more vegan possible options on the menu. My sister ordered the crab crepes without a problem.  Both of our meals were still good, they just new to fix their vegan/vegetarian items on their menu.
Love this place and its atmosphere. Always a great spot for a weekend brunch or week day breakfast if you are playing hookie!

Today was my first visit to the Square Cafe, and I'll absolutely return.   When my roommate and I arrived today, we were greeted to full tables (both inside and out) and a long queue of people waiting to be seated.  Although this looked like it would be at least an hour wait, we were told it would only be around 15 minutes.  Deciding not to wait for a table, a counter seat became available just minutes later, and we took those instead.  Although it was crowded, there was good flow in and out, so I don't doubt that the 15 minute estimate would have been close.  The food.... amazing choices here.  I'm vegetarian and my roommate is vegan, which poses an incredible challenge in Pittsburgh for no apparent reason.  The selections were clearly marked "V" for vegetarian and "VE" for vegan, although we were told that many of the V can be made VE quite easily.    As others have noted, the coffee here is fresh, bottomless and served in cool, square mugs.  No doubt, the squareness of the mugs adds to the taste.  I had the breakfast burrito with some added soy chorizo.  It came with sour cream and salsa.  Good vegetarian food is more than just a combination of plant-based ingredients.  When done right, it's truly amazing and makes you go, "wow!"  My breakfast was a home run!  Just the right size, and just the right combination of flavours.  My roommate had pancakes that were flavoured with pecans, cinnamon and other good things that reminded me of a big coffee cake-like-something that my mom always used to have around the house for company.  They were quite tasty as well, although I could never eat all that fluffy pancake mass by myself.  He could barely finish his meal.  After breakfast, I had a lemon bar (out of this world with just the right tartness and lemony goodness).  These are hidden on the counter, so  you need to look there when you go.  One of my biggest gripes with restaurants in Pittsburgh is the service which generally ranges from lackluster to downright awful.  Not here!  Sitting at the counter, we had the chance to talk to several of the folks that worked there.  The owner came over and introduced herself.  We didn't wait for anything (even the food, which came surprisingly fast for the crowd they had), but we were not pestered in search of a big tip either.  One important thing was apparent... everyone who works here really likes what they do and it shows.    Additional points to the staff for knowing that some of the ingredients in certain items were not vegan.  That's pretty rare, and often requires a trip to "ask the chef."    I left here happy today and that's saying a lot for a first trip to a new place.  There's nothing I would have changed, but so many other things I want to try that I'll HAVE to go back!

I typically LOVE Square Cafe (which is why I'm giving it 5 stars) but I just got take out from there and the brussel sprout hash was almost inedible because it was so salty. I'd think twice about ordering that, but everything else I've ever had has been delicious. And the wait staff are always very nice.

Loved it!  Visiting home and most of the food available was meat and potatoes...But not here!  Definitely a cut above and interest beyond the norm! Allergy aware and may delicious and interesting options to try.  And the coffee! best coffee we had in the Burgh - brewed or specialty.  Had brewed regular there and got a latte to go!  What they are doing, they are doing well. Also square mugs??? Thought it would feel akward in  my hands, exact opposite.  Brought one home to the ATL and only wished I had brought more.
Such an awesome hipster place! Great food, great atmosphere  You got to try the brussels sprouts hash, most excellent.  Come for breakfast or lunch you won't be disappointed

Jumping local breakfast joint, and one of the very few places in Pittsburgh to get a vegan breakfast.   I ordered the the vegan pancakes, with fig compote, which were great. What was disappointing was that there were only 2 vegan mains on the menu (quite a few more were vegetarian). I also got a side of fruit, which was OK, although the grapes might have been a little moldy. The coffee was great though.   Gf's breakfast burrito (not vegan) apparently was pretty bland, and because of the limited options, I can't give it 5 stars.   Still, for vegans, this is still one of the best places to go. Just go early, since it's very busy.

Absolutely adorable. I love the Square Cafe, and if I lived near here, I would make it a weekend breakfast tradition. The staff here are amazing, very nice and laid back. The decor is cute, but not in-your-face. Even the plates and glassware is cute! I ordered the key lime pancakes, which I was a little on the fence about. It was their special for the day and I love key lime pie, so I just ordered it and decided to take the risk. The pancakes were amazing!!! It was key lime with some berries, a perfect balance of tart and sweetness. I was really happy with the decision. My friend ordered the fruit crepes... I won.

We were traveling through Pittsburgh on a road trip and some friends recommended this place as a good place for plant based, vegetarian / vegan meals. We decided to try it out. We waited 30 minutes to be seated which was okay since it seemed like a really popular place. Our waitress wasn't very welcoming. I asked if we could have plain buttered pasta for our son and she asked in the kitchen and said no special requests. I then asked if they had any raw veggies or plain fruit and she said no. My chickpea sandwich was good but my mixed greens weren't edible. The lettuce was wilted and brown, who ever made up my plate obviously didn't care about the quality of the food.   I appreciate a restaurant where the menu has healthy choices but it seems that the staff and chef should be more concerned about the happiness of the customer.   Wish we had went to the East End Co-Op instead.

I was passing through Pittsburgh on a road trip and Square Cafe came highly recommended from several people as a great breakfast/brunch/lunch spot. 2pm on a Monday it was pretty empty since they were closing soon but man am I glad I got to try it. Brussels sprout hash for the win! Wow! So so so good! It was so fresh, filling, and delicious, the perfect lunch for fueling a long car ride!  The restaurant itself is absolutely adorable too, and located on such a cute small town USA-type of street. The service is good, food comes out quickly, and the prices are great too!

Square cafe is where it's at in the weekends! If you are looking for a place that has a great variety of food choices and amazing coffee, this is the place to go.   The menu is vast and has options to satisfy many food restrictions, both for breakfast and lunch. They offer vegetarian options as well as carnivore options. One of my favorite dishes is the French toast with the vegan compote. Tofu scramble is a really close second. Chocked full of earthy veggies and delicious flavors, it won't disappoint.   The venue itself is on the smaller side. During the warmer months, tables are set up outside and the available seating expands by close to double. In the winter, it can be tough to get a table inside. There is typically a wait but it's definitely worth it. The seating is a bit cramped, which is the only reason it doesn't get a full five stars. Parking can also be challenging in Regent Square, and side streets are your bet option.   If you're looking for a new place to try, I highly recommend!

Tucked in the middle of Regent Square, Square Cafe is a neat breakfast spot to check out. They specialize in their vegetarian and vegan dishes and their full service coffee/espresso bar at the front of their restaurant. I ordered the breakfast burrito. It was filling and flavorful! I also got a vanilla latte which was a warm addition on a cold, windy day. If you're looking for a place that offers unique breakfast combinations (try the lemon berry ricotta pancakes) then you should definitely try this place out!
Solid breakfast place, very small, always a wait.  Menu is ok not great

I heard so many great things about Square Cafe and couldn't wait to try it.  It is located on the cute street of South Braddock in Regent Square and always has a huge crowd of people waiting outside. Get there early to get a seat as it is packed on the weekends.  We went on an early Sunday morning and were able to get a seat for two outside with no wait which I wasn't expecting but it was perfect!  I had the avocado bacon omelet which was amazing-stuffed with bacon and tomatoes and topped with fresh avocado.  We also tried the breakfast tacos but beware they are super spicy.  On a past visit I had the oatmeal pancakes and French toast which were simply delicious.  Great place for kids and you can sit outside with your dog.

The only thing square about this place is the tables. Their menus and interior was really well done, but their portions are insanely small. It felt like I was having a kids meal.   I got the square breakfast for $10 which included 2 eggs with a choice of meat and pancake. I emphasize pancake, because you only get 1 piece.   For $10 you could've easily given me an extra pancake, or an extra piece of sausage, or use bigger eggs?   To whoever reading this, go elsewhere if you're hungry because you won't be full here.

There's a lot of good going on at this place. Was first introduced through recommendations of friends who raved about it, so that was encouraging. As I've tried it on several occasions, thought it was time for a review. I've generally liked my experiences here, but what I appreciate most is the family friendly, community vibe. They're also known for their support of fellow local businesses. I've tried their sweet and savory dishes. In the past, I've had the root medley, brussel sprout hash, breakfast burrito, pancakes, and seasonal coffees (have more pics than shown here). The lemon ricotta pancakes are what have stood out the most, and I'll definitely go back for those! They change up the hot bevies seasonally which is fun. I chose the standard square breakfast this last time, it comes with your choice of meat. The menu for my meal says "and toast", but I was charged extra for it. Not sure if I misinterpreted something. The dish was okay, and that's generally how I feel about their food. It's not been consistently good in each of the dishes I've tried. It's in the middle of the road cost wise, but that's because of the quality of their food and their local sources, which I understand. My last check did take me aback for a simple breakfast though. A fellow yelper pointed out the plate share fee, which I have never seen or heard of. With that said, I do like this place, for the cozy neighborhood vibe and friendly customer service. Great outdoor seating during warmer days. Place gets packed so plan ahead!
The food was ok, I had the corned beef Benedict. Very busy the service not that good.

I never thought I'd enjoy floppy pancakes, but somehow these were amazing.  A little sweet and packed full of flavor.  The sausage was also ridiculously good.    Square Cafe has inspired me to start a new list...  I got there a little after it opened and it filled up quickly thereafter.

Square is great!  I'm a vegetarian, so having the soy sausage, tofu, and meatless dishes available is wonderful.  I've never had a bad meal there.  I also love that they typically offer a fill up and to-go cup for your coffee before you leave.  I was recently there with my son, who loves it as well (very kid friendly), and I got one of their signature dishes - the Brussels sprouts over cheesy polenta, with a soft boiled egg on top, and some soy sausage as a replacement for ham.  OMG - best.breakfast.ever!  I ate the whole, HUGE, dish.  I will definitely be back for that.  I think the two big drawbacks to Square are these: 1.  A bit pricey.  This isn't your typical corner diner.  Even though we live close, we only go once in a while.  Its a great place to take guests from out-of-town, or to go for a special treat.  However, going on a weekly basis might break the budget a bit.  2.  Seating.  Most greasy spoons have horrible seating though, right?  Especially during peak times (Saturday and Sunday mornings).  People are practically sitting on top of each other, and wait staff has to do magic tricks in order to get orders to tables.  This is annoying, but its a popular place.  If you're looking for a quiet breakfast on a Sunday, Square is not for you.

This is primarily a breakfast place? REALLY??? I ordered my eggs over medium and got overcooked leathery eggs. If you can't serve up an egg correctly, you have no right serving breakfast. They are overpriced and the service is mediocre at best...  Does this place have anything going for it? The menu has lots of variation and is a standard urban mix of of what appear to be high quality ingredients... but if you don't cook them well, what am I paying for? A for effort and F for follow through?

One of the best breakfast food here. They have a variety to choose from and their shakes/smoothies are bombb. The first time I came I think I ordered one of their pancakes... but I came a second time today and ordered their Square Breakfast. I asked for scrambled eggs, breakfast sausage and a buttermilk pancake. Unlike other breakfast places, the food here isn't too greasy and heavy. Everything tastes clean and fresh. I would get their tiramisu shake if you can!   There's also outdoor seating which is really nice when the Pittsburgh weather clears up. I understand that when it gets busy, the service goes down a bit but both times that I've come, the service wasn't the best.

This is truly a great place to brunch (and I know my brunch: see my list for further details). I've only been here twice, mostly because it's a bit further away than other places in the East End and also because the wait here is generally a day and a half. The wait makes me want to bump this down to three stars, but I don't think I can because of the quality of the food and service. When I brunched here two weeks ago, they event put out blankets on all of the seats outside to keep the brunchers warm! But seriously, the people who work here are very nice. I've gotten the pumpkin pancakes (yyyyuuuuummmmm) and some sort of banana chocolate pancakes (double yum). And I love the cute coffee mugs they have for coffee and tea. I'll continue to stop in here once in a blue moon for my brunch needs.

This is place is adorably cute! I've come here on weekends and not waited a long time for a table for two. However, this place can get super crowded which lets you know how great the food is! I usually get a breakfast item, and they just changed their menu. An Egg Benedict dish seems to be the speciality, because I saw several of them upon entering the restaurant. Outdoor seating is available.
Awesome food, great service! Home made corned beef hash was amazing! So was the lemon ricotta pancake.

Square Cafe is charming and is worth visiting in the warmer months when you can sit outside. The menu is extensive although they did remove one item that we liked and kept us coming back. The food is delicious. I have always had good service despite being pretty busy. The only reason I rate it 4 stars is because their prices are excessive. It's worth visiting at least once for all of those who haven't tried it. I recommend purchasing a Groupon so that you aren't paying $20 pp for your breakfast.

Our absolute favorite breakfast spot in pittsburgh. Been here many times and it never disappoints. Super friendly service, amazing food, great coffee, cool space with local art on the walls. Also, very popular. Expect to wait for a table just about every time.   Here's the lowdown on food today. I ordered uncle Charley's hot sausage burrito. Eggs, sausage, beans, green peppers. Salsa. Sour cream. Delicious. Also had the home fries. Cooked and seasoned perfectly. Brussels sprout grits was also spot on. Very tasty grits. Pumpkin walnut pancake on the side that was the perfect sweet treat. Wash it down with their coffee and you've got a winner. Eat it!!

Square Cafe was INCREDIBLE & SUPER ACCOMMODATING to our large party! My entire family was in town for my cousin's college graduation, & we were wanting to find a local brunch spot. Since we had a party of 14 & Square Cafe is a little small, the host and I figured splitting the group in half would be the best idea. It ended up working out perfectly because the entire party didn't show up right away, and the host was so kind enough to reserve a table next to our table despite the Cafe being busy and crowded! In the end, the entire family was able to enjoy brunch together!!   I wish I had taken pictures of our food because everything was amazing! I got the Brussels sprouts hash, & I would definitely order that again! My family was raving about the burgers, & the salmon omelette! Not to mention their coffee & breakfast food was delicious as well :) We had the best server, Steven, who was super friendly and patient with our family. He even gave us some of his chalk calendars that he made as a little souvenir! Go check them out if you're in the area!!

I'm actually disappointed with my first Square Cafe experience. I ordered the Nutella crepes or I thought I did. When my food came out... I only received one crepe. There was an option to order one, but I ordered the crepeS --- plural. I didn't bother saying anything to the waitress about it because we only saw her twice the whole visit. Additionally, we had only one set of silverware, and I waited for well over five minutes before I was able get someone on the wait staffs attention. I also ordered bacon. 3 bacon strips for $5. Didn't really seem worth it to me to be honest.   Overall, the wait staff wasn't very attentive (they were busy, but It should not have taken me as long as it did to flag someone down for silverware) and the bacon was disappointing. However, the one crepe I had was really good. I wish I would have received the full order!

I love love love Square Cafe. We drive by often in our way to work and the place is always bustling at breakfast. We stopped on a weekday around lunch to avoid the rush, and had a Groupon in hand. No issue at all using it, like some small businesses. My husband had a breakfast quesadilla of some sort that was fantastic. The tortilla was freshly made, eggs were light and fluffy and the sausage was perfectly seasoned. I'm a big breakfast fan. I had the hazelnut pancakes. They were good. But not as good as my husband's dish. There was plenty of seating inside and out. We finished brunch with a fresh smoothie, which was light and not sickeningly sweet. Can't wait to go back again!

This my favorite place!  I go every other Saturday so the nostalgia of my first experience doesn't ware off!  I absolutely love this place.  Every time I come I am never disappointed.  It heathy, delicious, and happy eating.  The workers are friendly, and so are the people who done.  Every month they feature a community artist work on their walls.  I have tried just about everything and to me it's all delicious!!  My absolute favorite right know... Since the menu changes every season... Is the Short Rib Benedict.  It comes with corn fritters topped with slow cook short ribs, caramelize onions two eggs over easy and hollandaise sauce served with fresh greens. Yummy!!!  I also love their Gluten Free Berry Pancakes serves with fresh berries and a drizzle of honey.  No syrup needed!  I recommend this place to all who want fresh, delicious options for breakfast and lunch!!!  You will enjoy!!

I'm giving it five stars because of the ambiance!  I walked in and was immediately greeted. It was packed full of people who seemed very pleased. Probably a lot of regulars.  Very clean and hip. They have outdoor seating and good iced coffee  The workers were very nice. I didn't get the chance to eat here because I already had breakfast but I plan to come back the next time I'm in town.  There's a get-go gas station at the corner and a theatre and several shops. Nice neighborhood.

Favorite breakfast spot in Pittsburgh!!!! We knew we stumbled on to a winner when we pulled up to the restaurant and the line was pouring out onto the sidewalk. We figured the food must be good with such a long line and almost left thinking the wait would be too long. The host told us the wait would be about 20 minutes and he was almost exact in his timing. So glad we waited!!   The place itself is very bright and cheery. Very colorful, interesting and locally sourced artwork. I knew I was in the right place when I saw the staff wearing T-shirts that said "Love Each Other" with unicorns and rainbow artwork.   Now on the the food - First of all it came out extraordinarily fast, cooked to perfection and prepared just the way I asked. I had eggs, homefries & Italian Chicken Sausage (which was amazing). For the table we shared the Lemon Blueberry Ricotta Pancakes, which were out of this world and the Brussel Sprout bowl which was superb!   Everything was amazing and the staff was excellent. Also, they serve a bottomless cup of Joe for $2.80 AND they will give you a to-go cup, which was greatly appreciated as we were making the long drive back to the Philadelphia area after brunch.  If you are looking for a delicious, reasonably priced meal in a beautiful, warm and accepting space, Square Cafe is your place. Can't wait to go back!

A great versatile brunch/lunch spot for any kind occasion.  I ate the Say Uncle sausage and my friend ordered a cheesesteak crepe. The crepe was especially tasty with a really savory sauce on it.   I would recommend this place for anyone looking for a good brunch spot in the burgh! If you're sick of Pamela's go check out Square cafe!

Awesome and creative menu, really good food and a fun atmosphere. They have the coolest coffee mugs too! The staff is the icing on the cake.. they are the sweetest. You are missing out if you have not dined here!

Yes, the staff is fun, attentive, helpful and super. Yes, the food is fabulous, inventive, hearty and delicious. Yes, it's a great place to grab breakfast and lunch outside during the warm days and inside during the cold days. These things have all been said before and will be said forever because Square Cafe is wonderful! You should also know that they mix some of the best milkshakes in Pittsburgh, which I feel not enough people remember about this place. They also cater off site, so you could still have their tasty bites when they're not open. I highly recommend it!

Ok. I admit it. I love breakfast.   I have been wanting to try this place but its a little out of my way so it took a while. The place is bustling and colorful!   Pros: Interesting omelets, creative menu, quirky coffee mugs, fast service, Nancy B's Cookies.   Cons: Smaller portion side  Overall: If I am in the hood I will definitely be back!!

Most of the stuff on the menu here is standard, but they do have some unique dishes. They also have a TON of Veg options, which is nice. I got the mushroom melt... It was ok, but a friend got the special, which was croissant french toast.. It was amazing!!!

Definitely a cute place and a nice, bright way to start the morning.  The service is awesome.  Lemon ricotta pancakes are definitely where it's at.  I wasn't a big fan of the pulled pork eggs bene..kind of dry and bland.  It's a bit overpriced for a breakfast spot.  Coffee is really great, and I love the mugs that it's served in.

Square Caf√© is a great place with a diverse menu that includes vegan and vegetarian options. The space is rather tight and crowded, but that's a good sign that they are always packed. The food is always delicious and unlike anything you can get at a typical breakfast or lunch chain. I wish they'd open a few more locations around Pittsburgh!

By the time we'd arrived at Square Cafe we'd walked four miles through Frick Park and to two restaurants that were reportedly open but weren't on the fourth of July, so I figured my review might be tainted by the fact that I was ready to eat tree bark when I got here.  But even once my initial hunger was satiated, it was delicious.I mean, really crazy delicious. I got chicken crepes with mushrooms and I could have eaten a second...not because they are small, but because they are the type of excellent food that encourages me to overeat. My brother got salad and pancakes (he's weird like that) his wife also got the crepes and I think he felt left out. They were that good.   Super adorable interior and friendly service. And reasonable prices.  When I think of places I'd like to live if I move back to PA, Regent Square comes right to the top of the list and I have to give the square some kudos for factoring the neighborhood into consideration :)

I lived in Pittsburgh for a bit 20 years ago and still like to visit when I can. The food scene has just been exploding in wonderful ways, and this place is a fine example. The ambiance is clean and bright and cozy, if a little snug. Beautiful, funky decor. Service was fantastic, friendly but not a surveillance state. The coffee was sooooo gooood! And my pesto scramble was a great brunch. Tasty brioche toast and potatoes came with it, and I also got some maple sausage links. Price on all this seemed quite reasonable. Many great looking menu items ensure I'll make another visit next time I'm in town!

Square Cafe is absolutely my favorite place to go for breakfast/brunch.  We have been there more times than I can count, and nearly every time is wonderful.  The food tastes so fresh and delicious.  I also love how great they are towards kids AND dogs!  We take our son and chihuahua there in the summertime so that we can sit outside and enjoy the day.  Most of the time they'll bring her over some water to drink - very nice.  The choices as far as food goes are great, and the coffee is (almost) always very good!  I'm a vegetarian, so it's really nice to have a place that is veggie-friendly with lots of choices (that's also very rare).  And the breakfast potatoes are AWESOME!  The only reason I give Square Cafe four stars instead of five is because of their prices.  They are pretty overpriced actually.  I almost always get the same thing (Veggie Overload Omelet - yum!), but it's painful to have to pay over $2 extra to add cheese to it... sigh... but I still do it.    Square Cafe will continue to get our business for a many yerrs to come.

I've heard the praises of square cafe for years but have resisted it's indirect advances as best I could. I gave in today, and I'm super happy about it. We had the Brussels sprout hash and tot hash and they were both insane good. Gemma, our waitress, is maybe the nicest person ever. I want to be friends after this. Great coffee, I'll be back to try more and high five the waiters all over the place!

Love Square Cafe! Live nearby and have gone several times. Outdoor seating is great. Today I sat indoors which is just as nice. Super kid friendly. I would recommend going during the week opposed to the weekend. Less busy and no wait time. I have ordered several things off the breakfast menu and its always good. Today I ordered the chorizo omelet and that did not disappoint. This place would be 5 stars if everything was about $2 less.

The Square Cafe has good food and solid coffee in an independent atmosphere serving more "ethical" and healthy food than most diners. This makes it a little more expensive than most places you get bacon and eggs, but the food and service are solid.   Breakfast places are usually a greasy and comforting start to my day- bacon, eggs, toast, hash browns etc. Square Cafe has all these, but they get all their food as locally and organically as they can. The food tastes great, and the coffee is good, but be prepared to spend more here than you would at Denny's or Eat'n'Park, or Pam's. The bacon is thick cut and awesome, the eggs are done right and the coffee has caffeine.   The staff is great- attentive without hassling you and sitting outside is a great experience.

I just can't get enough of this place. Love it here. I am dieting and have lost 24#. It was important to me to be able to stick to my diet. I PM'd Square on FB and asked to create my own meal. They said no problem but then I got there and looked at the menu and said I am having what I want and I will just be responsible to stay within my calorie limits for the day. I had the Latke Lox. Incredible!!!!  It is a potato pancake topped with smoked salmon, sliced tomato and two eggs then sprinkled with red onion, capers and more tomato. I kept my hollandaise on the side so I could control this delectable sauce.  This is my new favorite. I say this after almost every meal here. And life it too short not to have a Stormy Chai. So silky smooth and tasty. I only had a small. I miss my usual 20 oz but 12oz is better than 0. Now I enter everything I eat into MyFitnessPal. I needed to know how many ounces of salmon I had so I asked. I briefly explained that I was logging all my calories and greatly appreciated her help.
